intro.para:
An arrow
Illustration
Pictures of arrows.
is a convenient tool to express the location of one point in relation to another. The location of an arrow in space is completely determined by the location of its tail, its length and its direction. If we allow the arrow to move in space while keeping its length and its direction, we obtain a vector.
We will see that this feature renders vectors an extremely versatile tool in our efforts to describe the world around us.

info.caption: Meaning of ‘Equivalent Arrows’
info.para: These two arrows are equivalent exactly when the instructions of moving from tip to tail are the same. As a consequence, equivalent arrows have the same length and direction.

subsection.body.para:
In the first expression the n-tuple (x_1,\dots ,x_n) characterizes the location of a point. In the second expression the same n-tuple forms a coordinate vector. This ambiguity in notation is firmly entrenched in the literature. Fortunately, we can untangle it nicely if we keep in mind the following dictionary for translating between points and vectors. position vector
The position vector of a X point in \RNr[n] is represented by the arrow \Arrow{\Vect{0}}{X} joining the origin to X.
